title: Why We Can't Quit Plastic | Earth.Org
body: The argument is that plastic is necessary to prevent food waste; roughly one third, or 1.3 billion tonnes, of the food produced for human consumption gets lost or wasted every year.
readable_content:
- Claudia Chow (2023-12-08): Plastic has become an inevitable part of consumer behavior, contributing to the plastic waste problem. The packaging sector alone is responsible for almost half of the plastic in the world. Plastic packaging helps with food preservation, but a large amount ends up in landfills. The challenge of recycling plastic also persists, as only 14% of plastic packaging is collected for recycling. Bioplastic alternatives have their own set of challenges, and using none at all would require sacrificing convenience. While the push towards a less plastic-centric world is evident, it's clear that completely cutting out plastic is not simple.

Would you like to read the full article?
summary:
The sentiment of this text is that while there is a push towards reducing plastic usage, completely cutting out plastic is not a simple task due to its integral role in consumer behavior and the challenges associated with viable alternatives.
